metadata.title: Texas Solar Permit Requirements by Jurisdiction
data_sources: City permitting websites and official documents
Austin Build + Connect / Austin Energy (austintexas.gov, austinenergy.com)

sb_1202.name: Residential Backup Power Permitting Streamlining
sb_1202.summary: Allows licensed third-party professionals (engineers or certified inspectors) to review and inspect residential backup power systems in place of city building departments. If city permitting takes longer than 2 business days, private vendors may approve home solar, battery, and generator installations.
sb_1202.impact: Significant acceleration of residential solar permitting statewide

sb_1252.name: Residential Energy Storage Permitting
sb_1252.summary: Municipalities can no longer regulate installation or inspection of residential energy backup systems for generators up to 50kW and solar/ESS up to 100kWh storage capacity.
sb_1252.impact: Reduces municipal permitting barriers for battery storage

sb_1036.name: Solar Consumer Protection - TDLR Registration
sb_1036.summary: Requires solar retailer registration with Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation (TDLR)

sb_1697.name: Solar Consumer Protection - PUCT Guide
sb_1697.summary: Requires PUCT-developed consumer information guides for all utilities

hb_431.name: Solar Roof Tiles HOA Protection
hb_431.summary: Amends Texas Property Code Section 202.010 to explicitly include solar roof tiles in the definition of solar energy device
hb_431.impact: HOAs cannot prohibit or restrict solar roof tiles

key_provisions: HOAs cannot outright prohibit solar energy devices
HOAs can designate placement location on roof
Homeowner can petition for alternate location if it increases annual production by more than 10% (per NREL PVWatts)
HOAs may impose reasonable aesthetic restrictions (black/bronze/silver color, parallel to roofline, not above roofline)
HOAs may require Architectural Review Committee approval but cannot deny compliant installations
Solar roof tiles explicitly protected as of May 2025
SB 1626 closes developer prohibition loophole for subdivisions of 50 or fewer units

statewide_fire_setback_requirements.residential_hip_roof: 3-foot-wide clear access pathway from eave to ridge on each roof slope where panels are located
statewide_fire_setback_requirements.ridge_setback: Panels located no higher than 3 feet below the ridge for fire department ventilation operations
statewide_fire_setback_requirements.commercial_pathways: Designated pathways capable of supporting firefighter live loads

metadata.statewide_pe_stamp_general_rule: Systems exceeding 10kW typically require PE-stamped plans in major metros. Smaller jurisdictions may have different thresholds. Ground-mounted and carport systems usually require PE stamps regardless of size.

houston.name: City of Houston

permit_fees.fee_structure: Flat fee plus plan review (25% of permit fee)
permit_fees.notes: Fee varies by system size and complexity

required_documents: Declaration Supporting Building Permit Application (signed by property owner, validated against HCAD records)
PE-sealed, signed, and dated engineered sheets (Texas licensed engineer)
Specification sheets with approved logos for all solar equipment
Electrical plans compliant with NEC Article 690
Contractor license registration with City of Houston

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: All engineered sheets shall be sealed, signed and dated by a Texas licensed engineer

solarapp_plus.notes: Houston is the first and primary AHJ in Texas using SolarAPP+ automated permitting. Licensed contractors can use SolarAPP+ for residential PV applications.

inspections.utility_inspection: CenterPoint Energy inspection required before interconnection

processing_time.notes: SolarAPP+ provides instant automated approval for code-compliant residential PV systems

common_rejection_reasons: Missing or outdated equipment specification sheets
PE seal/signature missing or not from Texas-licensed engineer
HCAD ownership mismatch without proof of ownership
Contractor license not registered with City of Houston
Fire setback pathway violations (3-ft perimeter, 3-ft below ridge)

contact.solar_guide: CE1198 - Solar Photovoltaic Panel Permit & Inspection Guide and Checklist

setback_requirements.fire_code: IFC 605.11 - 3-ft perimeter, 3-ft below ridge, clear access pathways

special_notes: CenterPoint Energy interconnection application required before installation begins
SolarAPP+ is available for qualifying residential systems
All plans must be submitted electronically
Houston is the first Texas city to fully adopt SolarAPP+

san_antonio.name: City of San Antonio

permit_portal.name: BuildSA
permit_portal.plan_submission: BuildSA Plan Room (electronic upload after application)

permit_fees.fee_structure: Based on system valuation; plan review fees invoiced after completeness review
permit_fees.notes: Solar application is a subtype of the general-electric permit

required_documents: BuildSA online application (building module tab, type SOLAR)
PE-stamped structural and electrical plans (for systems >10kW)

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: Structural review required for complex installations

solarapp_plus.notes: San Antonio is piloting SolarAPP+ as of 2024-2025

types: Final inspection / CPS Energy Commissioning Test
inspections.utility_inspection: CPS Energy Commissioning Test required after DSD releases permit
inspections.notes: CPS Energy will only schedule Commissioning Test after DSD permit is released

processing_time.notes: Completeness review is first step before technical reviews begin

common_rejection_reasons: Incomplete documents (fails completeness review before technical review)
Mismatched site plan and electrical diagrams
Solar array exceeding 150-ft on any one side

contact.solar_bulletin: Information Bulletin IB153 - Solar Photovoltaic Systems

setback_requirements.array_max_dimension: Solar arrays shall not be greater than 150-feet on any one side

special_notes: CPS Energy is municipal utility - no retail choice
Contractors must be registered with CPS Energy
CPS Energy net metering/buyback program available
San Antonio market has lower electricity rates - ROI may be longer
No residential ITC since Jan 2026 - focus on TPO/lease arrangements

dallas.name: City of Dallas

permit_fees.fee_structure: Separate building and electrical permits; fees paid by check or money order
permit_fees.notes: No fees required for initial plan submission; payment required before approval. Fees must be paid by check or money order.

required_documents: Site plan with panel layout and dimensions

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: Both structural and electrical PE stamps may be needed

solarapp_plus.notes: Dallas is reportedly considering SolarAPP+ adoption but has not launched as of early 2026

inspections.review_process: Sequential review (building, electrical, and fire reviewers review in sequence, not simultaneously)
inspections.notes: Sequential review process is a known bottleneck - reviewers do not work simultaneously

processing_time.notes: Sequential review process causes delays. Multiple city staffers review one at a time.

common_rejection_reasons: Incomplete site plans or electrical diagrams
Discrepancies between site plan and electrical one-line

setback_requirements.fire_code: IFC 605.11 standard setbacks (3-ft perimeter, 3-ft below ridge)

special_notes: Sequential review process makes Dallas one of the slower permitting jurisdictions
No fees for initial plan submission - payment at approval
Payment by check or money order only
Oncor handles interconnection separately
Two separate permit portals historically (now unified in DallasNow)

austin.name: City of Austin

permit_portal.name: Austin Build + Connect (AB+C)
permit_portal.austin_energy_portal: Austin Energy Distributed Generation Planning Application

permit_fees.fee_structure: Streamlined green energy permit; varies by system size
permit_fees.notes: Fast-track processing available. Austin Energy has separate fee schedule for interconnection.

required_documents: Austin Energy Distributed Generation Planning Application (DGPA)
One-line electrical diagram (PE-stamped or NABCEP certified for residential)

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: NABCEP certification may substitute for PE stamp on some residential plans. Commercial projects require full PE-stamped plans and DSD Commercial Plan Review.

solarapp_plus.notes: Austin has its own streamlined process through Austin Energy but does not use SolarAPP+

inspections.pre_construction_meeting: Recommended with Austin Energy inspector before installation
inspections.notes: Austin Energy recommends pre-construction meeting to review finished electrical drawings

processing_time.interconnection_timeline: 4-6 weeks total for interconnection and installation process
processing_time.notes: Residential DGPA does not need Austin Energy pre-approval before proceeding to permit

setback_requirements.austin_specific: Must comply with 2021 IRC and current NEC adopted codes

special_notes: Austin Energy is municipal utility - no retail choice
Austin Energy Solar Standard Offer Program provides rebates
January 2025 Solar Permitting Manual available online
Auxiliary Power permit type used for solar installations
Pre-construction meeting with Austin Energy inspector recommended
Residential DGPA can proceed without Austin Energy pre-approval

fort_worth.name: City of Fort Worth

permit_fees.fee_structure: Based on project valuation; development fees schedule available on city website
permit_fees.notes: Single combined permit (building + electrical) for residential solar

required_documents: Complete set of plans (panel layout, electrical, structural if needed)
Urban forestry permit (if common ownership equals 1 acre or more)

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: Structural review requirements vary based on system complexity

solarapp_plus.notes: Fort Worth has its own online permitting via Accela but does not use SolarAPP+

inspections.notes: Inspections can be scheduled online; residential solar uses series of guided questions on website

processing_time.notes: Fort Worth has streamlined to single permit for residential solar

common_rejection_reasons: Missing PE stamps for larger systems
special_notes: Single permit process (combined building + electrical) for residential solar
Website uses guided questions to determine correct permit type
Online application and inspection scheduling available
Urban forestry permit may be needed for larger properties

el_paso.name: City of El Paso

permit_portal.name: Accela Citizen Access
permit_portal.plan_submission: Online via Citizen Access Portal or in-person at One-Stop Shop

permit_fees.fee_structure: Based on project valuation per city fee schedule

required_documents: Permit application via Citizen Access Portal

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: Hurricane-zone engineering not typically required (inland location)

solarapp_plus.notes: El Paso has cross-trained inspection and permitting staff on solar PV but does not use SolarAPP+

inspections.scheduling: Via Citizen Access Portal or in-person
inspections.utility_inspection: El Paso Electric field inspection required after final city electrical inspection
inspections.notes: Contractor must contact EPE for field inspection and meter installation after final city inspection

processing_time.notes: El Paso has streamlined permitting with cross-trained staff

common_rejection_reasons: Missing PE stamps for larger systems
special_notes: Solar allowed as by-right accessory use in all zones
Cross-trained inspection and permitting staff on solar PV
SolSmart designated community
El Paso Electric is regulated utility (no retail choice)
EPE interconnection application fees: $85 (1-100kW), $230 (>100kW)

arlington.name: City of Arlington

permit_fees.notes: Arlington consolidated to single permit (previously required separate residential and electrical permits)

inspections.scheduling: Online via permit portal or in-person at City Hall

common_rejection_reasons: Missing PE stamps for larger systems

setback_requirements.sb_1202_note: SB 1202 applies to solar panels, battery storage, and standby generators

special_notes: Arlington streamlined to single permit (previously required separate permits)
Online application, payment, and inspection scheduling available
SB 1202 explicitly referenced for solar/battery/generator systems

corpus_christi.name: City of Corpus Christi

permit_portal.name: Dynamic Portal
permit_portal.notes: Apply for permits, view status, upload documents, pay fees, schedule inspections

permit_fees.notes: First-time users must apply for online account

required_documents: Exterior elevations (window sills, ceiling heights, eave heights, wall finishes)
Building sections with typical framing members and specifications

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: Coastal area - hurricane-zone engineering may be required for wind load calculations

setback_requirements.wind_zone: Coastal wind zone - ASCE 7-22 wind load standards apply

special_notes: Coastal location requires hurricane-zone engineering considerations
Wind load analysis per ASCE 7-22 standards required
Dynamic Portal handles full permitting lifecycle online

plano.name: City of Plano

permit_portal.name: E-TRAKIT
permit_portal.notes: Must be a registered contractor/designer to submit electronically

permit_fees.notes: No fees required for initial plan submission

processing_time.notes: Plano has a turnaround goal of 3 days for review and comments on residential applications

common_rejection_reasons: PE stamp deficiencies for larger systems
special_notes: Fast 3-day turnaround goal for residential permit review
No fees for initial plan submission
Must be registered contractor to submit electronically
Active Plano Solar Advocates community group

laredo.name: City of Laredo

permit_portal.name: City of Laredo Building Development Services

permit_fees.notes: Ordinance addresses Solar Panel Permit, Pre-Development Meeting, After-Hour inspection, and Partial inspection fees

inspections.notes: After-hour and partial inspections available per Ordinance 2024-O-247

special_notes: Solar Panel Guide available as Bulletin 001
Fee schedule updated by Ordinance 2024-O-247
After-hour inspections available

lubbock.name: City of Lubbock

permit_fees.fee_structure: Electrical permit fee based on system size

required_documents: LP&L interconnection agreement (must be completed FIRST)

inspections.notes: City inspection required before LP&L interconnection approval

processing_time.notes: LP&L interconnection agreement must be completed before permit application

special_notes: MUST complete LP&L interconnection agreement BEFORE applying for permit
LP&L is municipal utility - no retail choice
Electrical permit (not building permit) is primary permit type
LP&L solar FAQ available online

irving.name: City of Irving

permit_fees.fee_structure: Paid via MGO portal at conclusion of application process
permit_fees.notes: Permit issued after payment and license verification on state website

required_documents: MGO permit application (Solar Panel permit type)

inspections.scheduling: Online via MGO; deadline is 6 AM on business day requested
inspections.notes: After 6 AM, next business day is earliest available

processing_time.notes: Irving has a reputation among installers as one of the most challenging jurisdictions

special_notes: WARNING: Multiple installers report Irving as one of the most challenging jurisdictions for solar permits
Some installers avoid Irving entirely due to permitting difficulties
Separate permits required for solar energy systems
Inspection scheduling has strict 6 AM daily deadline
MGO portal technical support: (866) 957-3764

garland.name: City of Garland

permit_portal.name: City of Garland Building Inspections
permit_portal.notes: Documents submitted on USB in PDF format with paper copy of Subcontractor Permit Application

permit_fees.notes: One of the most transparent and affordable fee structures in the DFW area

required_documents: State of Texas Engineered plans for installation
Electrical engineer stamp (when no structural work needed)
Structural engineer stamp (when roof modifications required)
All documents on USB in PDF format

pe_stamp_requirement.description: 10kW-AC maximum exception; systems above require additional PE review
pe_stamp_requirement.structural_pe: Required when roof modifications are needed

inspections.utility_inspection: GP&L installs bi-directional meter after all inspections approved

common_rejection_reasons: Documents not on USB in PDF format
Company not registered as Electrical Contractor with City
special_notes: GP&L is municipal utility - installs bi-directional meter after approval
Documents MUST be on USB in PDF format
Paper copy of Subcontractor Permit Application also required
Solar companies must be registered with City as Electrical Contractor
Transparent flat fee structure: $175 total

frisco.name: City of Frisco

permit_fees.residential_formula: $75 + $0.59 per square foot of gross area

required_documents: Online permit application via Plans & Permits system
Site plan with panel layout and dimensions

inspections.scheduling: Contractors via eTRAKiT; homeowners without contractor may request by email
inspections.notes: Inspection requests NOT accepted over the phone

common_rejection_reasons: Missing PE stamps for larger systems

contact.address: George A. Purefoy Municipal Center, 6101 Frisco Square Blvd, 3rd Floor, Frisco, TX 75034

special_notes: Fee is formula-based: $75 + $0.59/sqft, max $550
Inspections requested via eTRAKiT (contractors) or email (homeowners) only - no phone requests
Fee schedule last updated October 1, 2025

mckinney.name: City of McKinney

permit_fees.fee_structure: Per city fee schedule (Appendix A - Schedule of Fees)
permit_fees.notes: Fee schedule available via McKinney Code of Ordinances

required_documents: Online permit application via Citizen Self-Service
common_rejection_reasons: Missing PE stamps for larger systems
special_notes: Rapidly growing city - permitting volumes increasing
All inspections scheduled via Citizen Self-Service portal

round_rock.name: City of Round Rock

permit_fees.payment_methods: E-Check, Visa, or Mastercard via permit portal
permit_fees.notes: Simple flat fee of $150 - one of the more affordable in the Austin metro

required_documents: One complete set of one-line drawings stamped by electrical engineer (or NABCEP certified)
Torque letter (must be uploaded before final inspection - on letterhead with master's license number and signature)
Note: Structural drawings are NOT required

pe_stamp_requirement.description: Electrical engineer stamp (or NABCEP certification) required for one-line drawings regardless of system size
pe_stamp_requirement.notes: Round Rock accepts NABCEP certification as alternative to PE stamp

inspections.torque_letter: Must be uploaded before final inspection
inspections.notes: Torque letter must be on letterhead with master's license number and signature

common_rejection_reasons: Missing electrical engineer stamp or NABCEP certification on one-line drawings
Missing torque letter before final inspection

contact.department: Building Inspection Division - Planning and Development Services

special_notes: Structural drawings NOT required - simplified process
Flat $150 fee - affordable and transparent
NABCEP certification accepted as alternative to PE stamp
Torque letter required before final inspection
Online payment via E-Check, Visa, or Mastercard

sugar_land.name: City of Sugar Land

permit_fees.notes: Fee may change due to SB 1252 impact on permitting scope

required_documents: Compliance documentation for 2023 NEC (Texas adopted code)

pe_stamp_requirement.notes: Must be designed to 2023 NEC National Electrical Code

inspections.sb_1252_impact: Under SB 1252 (effective Sept 1, 2025), municipalities can no longer regulate installation/inspection of residential backup systems up to 50kW or storage up to 100kWh

special_notes: Strong HOA presence - ensure HOA approval before permitting
SB 1252 significantly impacts permitting scope for backup power systems
Must comply with 2023 NEC (state-adopted code)
CenterPoint Energy serves as T&D utility

denton.name: City of Denton

permit_portal.name: eTRAKiT Portal
permit_portal.notes: Building Safety Division upgraded to eTRAKiT portal

required_documents: Completed and signed DG Manual Permit Application (for DME customers) OR residential permit application
Structural engineering letter verifying roof capacity
Plans designed per 2021 IRC and 2020 NEC (City of Denton adopted codes)

pe_stamp_requirement.structural: Structural engineering letter verifying roof capacity required for all installations

common_rejection_reasons: Plans not compliant with 2021 IRC / 2020 NEC
Incomplete DG Manual Permit Application (DME customers)
special_notes: DME customers need separate DG Manual Permit Application
Structural engineering letter required for ALL installations (not just >10kW)
Must comply with 2021 IRC and 2020 NEC specifically
Aerial views of panel locations required
DME is municipal utility - no retail choice

pearland.name: City of Pearland

permit_portal.name: CityWorks
permit_portal.notes: Submit applications, make payments, schedule inspections online

required_documents: Permit application (online via CityWorks or paper)
special_notes: CityWorks portal handles applications, payments, and inspection scheduling
Paper applications also available on website
CenterPoint Energy serves as T&D utility

leander.name: City of Leander

permit_fees.fee_structure: Per city ordinance fee schedule; technology fee added to all permits
permit_fees.notes: Refer to City of Leander Code of Ordinances for most current fees

required_documents: Online permit application via Development Hub
special_notes: Predominantly paperless permitting via Development Hub
Technology fee added to all permits
PEC (cooperative) serves as electric utility - different interconnection process than IOUs
Rapidly growing city in Austin metro

cedar_park.name: City of Cedar Park
required_documents: Online permit application via MGO Connect

inspections.scheduling: Via MGO Connect portal; inspections scheduled before 3pm listed on next business day
inspections.notes: Required inspections vary by project type

contact.address: 450 Cypress Creek Rd, Bldg 1, Cedar Park, TX 78613

special_notes: MGO Connect for online permit applications and inspection scheduling
PEC (cooperative) serves as electric utility
Inspections scheduled before 3pm appear on next business day
Contact Building division at 512-401-5100 for project-specific requirements

solarapp_plus.name: SolarAPP+
solarapp_plus.description: Free automated online permitting platform providing instant permits for code-compliant residential PV and PV-plus-storage systems
benefits: Same-day permit issuance for qualifying systems
Reduces review time from weeks to minutes

opensolar_permit.name: OpenSolarPermit
opensolar_permit.texas_adoption: Limited adoption in Texas as of early 2026
opensolar_permit.notes: No major Texas cities confirmed using OpenSolarPermit

third_party_plan_review.description: Under SB 1202 (effective Sept 1, 2025), licensed third-party professionals can review and inspect residential backup power systems if city permitting takes >2 business days
third_party_plan_review.impact: Available statewide as fallback when city process is slow
concerns: Potential bias since reviewers are hired/paid by installer

fastest_processing.notes: Instant for qualifying systems via SolarAPP+
Simplified process, no structural drawings required
